With these and suchlike reflections the praetorians kept their minds in agitation, by turns in- flamed with anger, or depressed with fear. They saw their ruined condition; despair succeeded, and from despair they derived courage and a spirit of revenge. XLV. The victorious army halted at the distance of five miles from Bedriacum. The generals did not think it advisable on the same day to attempt the enemy's camp. Expecting a voluntary surrender, they were willing to give their men some time to repose. To encamp was not in their power. The soldiers took the field, pre- pared for battle, unincumbered, and of course without the means of throwing up entrenchments.
